page_analysis.text_content:
Roofed porches on the 1st floor

How to determine if a porch is at least 50% open (using Fig 5 as an example)

Fig 5 Roofed 1st floor porch

Step 1: Determine the perimeter of the porch and divide it into
segments that will allow a comparison of closed and
open segments.

The perimeter of the porch in Fig 5 is shown below. It is the sum of
segments A throug G. It is 70 linear feet.

8

visual_elements.description: An isometric view of a two-story house with a roofed porch on the first floor. The porch extends along the front and side of the house, supported by columns. The house has multiple windows and a gabled roof.

A floor plan diagram of a porch, showing its perimeter divided into segments labeled A through F, with corresponding measurements. Segment A is 3', Segment B is 8', Segment C is 10', Segment D is 7', Segment E is 14', and Segment F is 24'. There is also an unlabeled segment G, which is implied to be part of the perimeter calculation.

technical_specifications.parameter: Total perimeter of porch (A through G)

subheadings: How to determine if a porch is at least 50% open (using Fig 5 as an example)

additional_notes: The word 'through' is misspelled as 'throug' in the sentence 'It is the sum of segments A throug G.'
The segment 'G' is mentioned in the text but not explicitly labeled or measured in the provided floor plan diagram, although its contribution is included in the total perimeter.

conditions.text: if a porch is at least 50% open

execution_sequence.action: Determine the perimeter of the porch and divide it into segments that will allow a comparison of closed and open segments.
